review_text: We rented this house for our wedding party the weekend of our wedding. I was so excited for the large backyard and enough bedrooms to fit all of my needs. When we arrived on site I was disappointed to see that the backyard was not large at all and did not have the fire pit that was in the photos. The house inside ended up fitting our needs, but was still not what we expected. The house is a historic home so the layout is kinda weird. The bedroom with the futons is connected to another bedroom where they have to go through it to go to the upstairs bathroom. The doors also did not lock and the king sized bedroom had a glass door that connected to the dining room with the curtain being broken so people could see into it. Also would not recommend this space for ADA accessibility if that is what you’re looking for. In addition, the hot tub only fit 5 comfortably even though the house was for a large group and make sure to read the description on parking so you know what you’re getting into.

review_text: An excellent apartment – very comfortable, well-furnished, very well-equipped, and in a great location. My wife and I, after spending a few very enjoyable days in Bay City in January, decided to return in October for another short break. We wanted to stay on or near Center Avenue, in the fascinating historic district, where there is an astonishing range of styles for the big houses and public buildings that Bay City’s confident lumber barons and industrialists built during the city’s boom years in the late nineteenth and very early twentieth centuries. As the Center Avenue Neighborhood Association (which produces an excellent walking-tour brochure) puts it: “Among our district’s 880 historic structures are examples of various architectural styles, including Arts & Crafts, Colonial Revival, Georgian Revival, Gothic Revival, Greek Revival, Italianate, Mid-Century Modern, Neo-Classical, Queen Anne, Richardsonian Romanesque, Second Empire, Shingle Style, Stick, and Tudor Revival, as well as kit homes by the Aladdin, Lewis, and Liberty companies.” This ground-floor apartment, running the length of a massive mock-Tudor house, was an excellent choice for us. It is one of two ground-floor AirBnB rentals; the upper floors of the house are divided into regular rental apartments. The elegant sitting room at the front of our apartment, with a lovely bay window, the large bedroom (one of two) with the four-poster bed in the middle, the dining room and spacious, well-equipped kitchen at the back were all perfect for us. Two parking spaces off the side road, one covered, were conveniently close to the back door, making unloading and loading easy. The apartment was spotlessly clean. In the kitchen we found everything we needed, except for a kettle and a teapot (but, as traveling tea-drinkers, we are used to having to bring our own supplies), and we enjoyed frothing our milk for the occasional coffee in the Keurig machine, among an array of excellent kitchen appliances, including a refrigerator with an ice-maker, a rarity, at least in my experience, in AirBnBs. We slept well on the very comfortable, king-sized mattress, despite a little traffic noise. The sitting room boasts an enormous TV screen, so that, although we don’t usually watch TV when we travel, this time we could not resist an hour of Netflix and some Premier League highlights (there is a good range of subscription services). WiFi was excellent and abundant power outlets made it easy to charge phones, laptops, camera batteries, etc, in every room; the USB ports in the bedside lamps on either side of the bed were particularly welcome. All the doors are secured with digital locks. Outside, a few minutes walk will take you past an extraordinary and eclectic range of buildings. We also used the apartment as a base for visits to the Dow Gardens and the Alden B. Dow house in Midland (both very well worth the short drive), to the Tobico Marsh nature trail on the shores of Lake Huron, and the Bay City historical museum – both excellent. Drinks at the Public House bar and its sister Harless and Hugh Coffee shop, and dinner at The Real Seafood Company, in an elegant, modern building on the riverfront, were all very enjoyable, as was lunch in Midland at Café Zinc in the elegant H Hotel. Midland’s Wednesday Farmers Market was surprisingly lively for late October. Our breakfasts and dinners at the apartment were a pleasure to prepare and to consume at the large dining table (which would comfortably seat six). There is a coin-operated washing machine in the basement, but we did not use it. We would happily return to this apartment and recommend it wholeheartedly.

I surprised my boyfriend for his birthday with the trip and the space definitely gave the "WOW! This is amazing!!" reaction I was hoping for. :) We drove up after work so I am very grateful we were able to do a bit later check-in. Communication with Lyndsay was always prompt, and she is so helpful.
The private rooftop patio was so wonderful to make some Harless + Hugh coffee and enjoy in the mornings. She has the place stocked with coffee gadgets so you can make your own perfect cup. Or you can go downstairs for a cup and enjoy the coffee shop's cute patio with locals.
All of the restaurants and bars are a short walk away, making it easy to play the weekend by ear. One of the mornings we rented kayaks on Saginaw River (only 6 minutes away). We also enjoyed the state park (I recommend the Tobico Trail head!) and stopped to dip our feet into Saginaw Bay (both are about 10 minutes away).
Could not recommend this place and Lyndsay as a host enough. Looking forward to the next time we can visit.

review_text:
This is a clean property in a great location. There are MANY shops and restaurants within walking area. (We recommend Gatsby's or River City for dinner and Mandy's for breakfast.)
We never had trouble finding street parking. There was a lot of live music in the area mid-week. There is a riverwalk located nearby that was great to walk on. Donald's unit is no frills...think clean bachelor pad. I would suggest bringing pillows from home if you like firmer pillows. Toiletries included were bar soap and shampoo for the shower and hand soap for the bathroom sink. We appreciated the soft toilet paper. Don't laugh...some places stock the stuff that is a step above sandpaper. The kitchen had the usual pots, pans, dishes, silverware. Don't expect a lot in the way of spices and other cooking essentials. This was fine for us as we ate out for all of our meals. Donald thoughtfully included 4 bottles of water, 4 cans of Coke, and 4 cans of Diet Coke chilling in the fridge. There are two bars located directly under the unit and the building is vintage, so if you are a light sleeper, bring earplugs and maybe have a white noise app on your phone. (To be clear, the bars catered to chatting adults, not rowdy college kids, but since we were there in the summer, there was outdoor seating outside the living area and one of the bedrooms.)
